column1: Vác (Hungarian pronunciation: [ˈvaːt͡s]; German: Waitzen; Slovak: Vacov; Yiddish: ווייצען‎) is a town in Pest county in Hungary with approximately 35
column2: 000 inhabitants. The archaic spelling of the name is Vácz.

column1: Vác is located 35 kilometres (22 miles) north of Budapest on the eastern bank of the Danube river
column2: below the bend where the river changes course and flows south. The town is seated at the foot of the Naszály Mountain in the foothills of the Carpathians.

column1: Vác is a commercial center as well as a popular summer resort for citizens of Budapest. The cathedral
column3: was modelled after St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. The episcopal palace houses a museum for Roman and medieval artifacts. The city is also known for its 18th-century arch of triumph and for its beautiful baroque city center.

column1: Settlement in Vác dating as far back as the Roman Empire has been found. The origin of its name is debated. One hypothesis says that the name comes from a Hungarian tribal name "Vath". Another theory says the name comes from czecho-slovak personal name Vac (Vác)
column2: which is the diminutive form of Václav.It has been the seat of a Roman Catholic bishopric since the 11th century. Bishops from the Roman Catholic Diocese of Vác were influential within the Kingdom of Hungary
column3: with many serving as chancellors or later becoming archbishops.

column2: due to the attack of Mongols the population was slaughtered and Mongols set up camp there. After the departure of the Mongols
column3: Vác was rebuilt and German colonists were invited to the town.The town was conquered by the Ottoman Empire in 1541. During the Habsburg Monarchy's wars against the Ottomans
column4: the Austrians won victories against the Turks at Vác in 1597 and in 1684. After the Great Turkish War
column5: Vác was rebuilt and repopulated. This re-population was both spontaneous and planned. According to the Truce of Zsitvatörök
column6: Habsburg control of the fortress at Vác (also known as Vacz) was maintained

column1: During the Hungarian Revolution and War of Independence of 1848-49
column2: the Honvédség routed the Austrian forces stationed in the city after a major battle (April 10
column3: 1849); the Second Battle of Vác ended in Russian victory (July 17).

column2: Vác was captured on 8 December 1944 by Soviet troops of the 2nd Ukrainian Front in the course of the Budapest Offensive.
